entry.title: Future Reserves 2020 Consultation
entry.summary: On 5 July 2012, the Secretary of State for Defence responded to the Review of the United Kingdom’s Reserve Forces published on 18 July 2011. Given the scale of change required, he requested the Ministry of Defence carry out a formal public consultation on how to achieve our vision for the Future Reserve Forces (FR20).
entry.content:
The United Kingdom’s Reserve Forces are a vital component of our Armed Forces; contributing to the public good we call Defence. They have made, and continue to make, a significant contribution to the Nation’s defence and security. But the security challenges the UK will face in future are different from those of the past, and for which our Reserve Forces are currently structured. Over the next decade, as Defence transforms to meet future and uncertain challenges, so the importance of our Reserve Forces will increase, and the way we organise and use them will change.

The consultation exercise will consider what changes are required to the Reserve Forces in order to generate and sustain the numbers and capabilities we need from them to meet our defence requirements. Specifically, we will look to define the right offer to attract and retain the individuals we need to serve in the reserves; the right relationship with the civilian employers of reservists; and the right support for reservists and their families across our communities.

The Consultation (Green) Paper sets out our thinking and direction of travel on Future Reserve. The key areas on which the paper focuses include:

  • How we will use Reserve Forces in the future
  • The offer for employers
  • The offer for reservists

Responses to the Green Paper can be provided online from early November. We encourage you to engage and provide feedback.

A White Paper in 2013 will detail the policy changes for Reserves and show how changes will be implemented to establish a new force structure such that we create the strategic conditions for success. Responses received during the consultation exercise will be used to inform the White Paper.

A case study of Iain Ballantyne, intelligence analyst with the RAF Reserves, can be found below.

Any enquiries or questions about the consultation process should be directed to DCDSPers-RFC-FR20Consultation@mod.uk. Please note this email address should not be used to send responses to the Green Paper - Please respond via the online survey at the Respond Online link below. entry.title: The business case for equality and diversity: a survey of the academic literature
entry.summary: Looks at the evidence for the business case for equality and diversity in private sector organisations.
entry.content:
This report sets out the findings from a systematic review of the literature on the business case for equality and diversity. It was commissioned by the Department for Business Innovation & Skills (BIS) and the Government Equalities Office (GEO).

The report aims to:

  • improve understanding of theoretical positions and issues related to the business case for equality and diversity
  • develop a consistent framework for assessing evidence on the business case
  • within this framework, review the evidence
  • create a compendium of the evidence

The research assesses the most robust evidence, draw implications from the findings and present a dispassionate picture of the evidence identifying gaps and conflicting messages. The report looks at diversity in terms of ‘protected characteristics’ that are defined in the Equality Act 2010.

entry.title: Guidance on the pre-application process for major infrastructure projects
entry.summary: This guidance sets out the requirements and procedures for the pre-application process and consultation for major infrastructure projects.
entry.content:
This document is the result of merging and expanding reworked versions of the local authority guidance and the pre-application guidance that went out to consultation on 13 April 2012. By merging these, we are avoiding unnecessary repetition of the description of common processes.

The new guidance sets out the necessary requirements and procedures and gives clarity on the scope and scale of the consultation required at the pre-application stage. It covers all the main processes required by an applicant prior to the submission of an application, including the pre-application consultation, Environmental Impact Assessment, Habitats Regulations Assessments, and advice on drafting a Development Consent Order.

entry.title: Reliability of journeys on the Highways Agency’s motorway and A road network
entry.summary: Impact indicator, disaggregated by junction, published monthly from May 2011.
entry.content:
DfT Business plan impact indicator

  • Geographical coverage: England
  • Information broken down by: national level aggregation

Latest data

  • Provisional data show that 81.9% of journeys made on Highways Agency managed roads between December 2011 and November 2012 were ‘on time’. This is 0.4 percentage points lower than the previous rolling year, ending in October 2012.
  • During November 2012, provisional data show that 76.6% of journeys on Highways Agency’s motorway and ‘A’ road network were ‘on time’. This is 4.7 percentage points lower than the equivalent figure for November 2011.
  • The annual reliability measure consistently increased up to March 2012, but has fallen in the last eight months, and is now at a similar level to that observed in mid-2011. 2012 was the second wettest year since records began with substantial rainfall during the final three quarters of the year. Significant amounts of rainfall compared to 2011 will have led to slower speeds on the network, slower journeys and thus a fall in reliability.

Click here to view this data in an interactive chart

Percentage of journeys on Highways Agency motorways and A roads deemed ‘on time’: monthly from June 2012

Percentage of journeys ‘on time’

  Year ending Month Year ending percentage points change
June 2012 83.3 82.3 -0.2
July 2012 83.0 81.8 -0.2
August 2012 82.9 81.9 -0.1
September 2012 82.6 80.5 -0.3
October 2012 82.3 79.6 -0.3
November 2012P 81.9 76.6 -0.4

Source: Highways Agency Traffic Information System (HATRIS) Database

P = provisional

Background information

This indicator monitors the reliability of journeys made on Highways Agency’s motorway and A road network.

The indicator is measured by the percentage of ‘journeys’ on these roads that are ‘on time’. For this measure:

  • a ‘journey’ represents travel between adjacent junctions on the network
  • an ‘on time journey’ is defined as one which is completed within a set reference time, drawn from historic data on that particular section of road
  • reference journey times are updated for the April data each year - further information on the impact of updating reference times can be found in section 3 of the latest statistical release

At present, information about the reliability of journeys on individual routes, or between particular junctions on the network, are not sufficiently robust to be presented as official statistics. This is due to the range of different sources used to calculate journey times across the network.

The Department has been working with the Highways Agency to address these issues of comparability. As a result we will be making a number of methodological changes to improve the quality of the reliability measure from the publication of the January 2013 statistics (in March). More detail on these changes will be provided in updated technical guidance.

Journey time reliability data for individual road sections is currently published by the Highways Agency through the data.gov.uk webpage.

  • next update: 14 February 2013

entry.title: Stopping up and diversion orders: reform of the application process for local highways
entry.summary: This consultation details proposals to simplify the process of applying for the stopping up and diversion of a highway.
entry.content:
Summary

Following the ‘Penfold review’, this consultation details proposals to simplify the process of applying for the stopping up and diversion of a highway where this is required for the purpose of property development.

We propose to permit applications for a stopping-up or diversion order to be submitted at the same time as applying for planning permission for the proposed development (whereas under the existing legislation the developer can only apply after securing planning permission), and options for devolving decision-making to the local authority level.

entry.title: Department for Transport equality monitoring
entry.summary: Summary of findings on equalities in employment at the Department for Transport.
entry.content:
These reports feature an analysis of staff diversity, for staff in post between 1 April 2011 and 31 March 2012. The analysis looks at staff in post, cessations, grievances and discipline, training, sickness absence, performance markings and recruitment, and considers whether there were significant differences with respect to sex, race, disability, pay band, age, sexual orientation, religion and belief and working pattern.
